guiding_thinkers: Robert Brandom, Wilfrid Sellars, John McDowell
description: Analyzes meaning through inferential roles, commitments, and entitlements in the space of reasons

assumptions: Meaning is inferential role - to understand a concept is to master its inferential connections
Discourse is normative - a game of giving and asking for reasons
Incompatibility is more fundamental than entailment
Different scorekeepers keep different scores - perspectival structure
Content is not fully determined in advance - retroactive determination possible
Expressive vocabulary makes explicit what is implicit in practice
core_tensions: Commitment vs Entitlement - what you're held to vs. what gives you the right
Undertaking vs Attribution - what you think you're saying vs. what others hear
Default vs Earned entitlement - what gets a free pass vs. what must be proven
Material vs Formal inference - content-based vs. form-based validity
scope_conditions: Applies to discursive practices and conceptual content
Requires social practices of giving and asking for reasons

primary_entities: Commitments - deontic statuses one is held to (not beliefs)
Entitlements - normative authority to make claims
Discursive scorekeeping - tracking who is committed to what
Package deals - bundled commitments that come together
relations: Commitment inheritance - downstream commitments from accepting claims
Entitlement inheritance - authority transferred through inference
Incompatibility - positions that cannot be held together
levels_of_analysis: Individual scorekeeping - what each participant tracks
Retrospective determination - how meaning gets fixed over time

change_mechanisms: Discursive move - utterances change normative landscape
Challenge and vindication - testing claims through reasons
Retrospective determination - future practice reveals past commitments
temporal_patterns: Progressive elaboration - concepts develop through use
Retroactive vindication - later developments reveal earlier commitments
Score evolution - normative standings shift through discourse
transformation_processes: Making explicit - expressive vocabulary reveals implicit norms
Conceptual engineering - deliberate revision of inferential roles
Paradigm revision - fundamental restructuring of commitments

key_concepts: Inferential commitment - what accepting a claim puts you on the hook for
Default entitlement - claims presumed okay unless challenged
Material inference - valid by content, not just logical form
Expressive vocabulary - words that make inferential moves explicit
Perspectival gap - difference between speaker intention and hearer attribution
Citation baggage - inherited commitments from endorsed sources
analytical_methods: Commitment mapping - what positions commit you to
Incompatibility identification - what you can't hold together
Entitlement auditing - what gives claims their authority
problem_diagnosis: Hidden commitments people don't realize they've incurred
Unearned entitlements - claims made without proper backing

trait_definitions.trait_description: Focus on normative statuses in discourse

critique_patterns.diagnostic: Accepting position without acknowledging downstream commitments
critique_patterns.fix: Make explicit that accepting {claim} commits you to {downstream}

critique_patterns.diagnostic: Asserting claim without proper backing or authority
critique_patterns.fix: Identify what would entitle one to claim {assertion}

critique_patterns.diagnostic: Treating speaker intention as equivalent to hearer attribution
critique_patterns.fix: Distinguish what {speaker} undertakes from what {audience} will attribute

critique_patterns.diagnostic: Cherry-picking from citation without inheriting full commitments
critique_patterns.fix: Acknowledge that endorsing {source} brings commitment to {baggage}

historical_context: Developed from Pittsburgh School pragmatism, building on Sellars and extending Kant/Hegel
